Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: RanKloud: Data Partitioning and Resource Allocation Strategies for Scalable Multimedia and Social Media Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Today, multimedia data are produced and consumed in massive quantities in a broad range of applications with significant economic and societal benefit, including e-commerce, surveillance, education, web services, and social media. Hence, there is an urgent need for systems to provide highly scalable processing and efficient analysis of large media data collections. The RanKloud prototype system, developed in this research project, focuses on the needs and requirements of applications that deal with large quantities of multimedia data in a cloud-based scalable environment.

Most multimedia applications share a few core operations, including integration/fusion, classification, clustering, graph analysis, near-neighbor search, and similarity search. When performed naively, however, these core operations are often very costly, because the number of objects and object features that need to be considered can be prohibitive. Avoiding this cost requires that redundant work is avoided. This research focuses on the next generation cloud-based massive media processing and analysis systems where the fundamental principles that govern their design include an awareness of the utilities of data and features to a particular analysis task. Incorporating data and feature utilities for performing a particular utility task is expected to significantly reduce the overall cost of the analysis task. The RanKloud project research plan includes: (1) data model and query language to specify multimedia data processing workflows; (2) adaptable, rank-aware parallel multimedia data processing primitives; (3) run-time data sampling strategies to support adaptation to data and resource; and (4) waste- and unbalance-avoidance strategies for utility-aware data partitioning, resource allocation, and for incremental batched processing.

RanKloud bridges an important gap in our understanding of cloud-based computing in general, and efficient processing of multimedia data in particular. The results are expected to enable new tools and systems supporting scalability in a large class of problems in content-aware multimedia and social media analysis with impact in web intelligence, business intelligence, and scientific and sensor applications all of which need to handle imprecise multimedia data for more effective decision making. This project provides research experience opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students and includes research results and challenges in courses, including Capstone projects. Arizona State University (ASU) recruits top-quality undergraduates through a nationally recognized residential Honors College and the Minority Access to Research Careers program. The national and international dissemination of the project results includes premier conference and journal publications, as well as open source software licenses at the RanKloud Web site (http://aria.asu.edu/rankloud).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today, data is being produced and consumed in a wide variety of applications, including surveillance, e-commerce, internet video, and social media sites, such as Flickr, Facebook, and YouTube. Multimedia and social media analysis tasks pose significant challenges and they necessitate highly parallelizable, and in many cases cloud-based, frameworks for scalable processing and efficient analysis of large media and social media collections. In order to support effective scaling through elimination of wasted work, we need new data and feature utility sensitive data partitioning, resource allocation, scheduling, and optimization techniques. In particular, tensors (multi-dimensional arrays) are widely used for representing such highorder dimensional data. Consequently, a system dealing with social media data needs to scale with the tensor volume and the number and diversity of the data facets. We have developing a scalable multimedia and social media retrieval and analysis middleware, called RanKloud, specifically sensitive to the needs and requirements of multimedia and social media analysis applications. The transformative intellectual outcomes of RanKloud included

(a) avoiding waste by intelligently partitioning the data and allocating it on available resources to minimize the data replication and indexing overheads and to prune superfluous low-utility processing;

(b) development of a tensor-based relational data model to support the complete lifecycle (from collection to analysis) of the data, including reducing the computational cost of various multi-dimensional data analysis operations, through parallel and incremental decompositions of static and dynamically evolving tensors, integration of tensor operations into a static or continuous query-processing worklow, and efficient structural change detection on tensor streams;

(c) efficient (including incremental and parallel) processing of preference/skyline queries over both static and streaming data sets and integration of skyline operators (over potentially imprecise and incomplete data sets) within SkySuite framework that support static or continuous query-processing workflows; and

(d) novel hierarchically cut selection (HCS) framework that uses hierarchically organized bitmap indices (reflecting the hierarchical metadata associated with the individual data dimensions) to enable I/O efficient execution of multi-query OLAP workloads over column-oriented data stores.

 

We have also developed social media network analysis algorithms (such as seed node selection for maximal information and influence spread) that can benefit from the proposed middleware. To date, we have developed the core algorithms and the various software components of the RanKloud. In particular, three sub-components of RanKloud (SkySuite, HCS, and Tensor DB) are publically disseminated as stand alone components. The project outcomes have been widely distributed through several journal and conference publications, keynote presentations, and conference organizations.

Overall, the project involved 2MS and 4 PhD students, 3 of whom were funded directly from this grant. These students have been trained in critical thinking, team collaboration, system develepment, evaluation and experimentation, as well as technical writing and presentation skills. Several of these students had the opportunity to presented their works in international conferences.
